Fabricating highly active non-noble metal catalysts for hydrodeoxygenation of lignin derivatives is craving but still a challenge. Herein, hierarchical Ga-promoted Ni/MFI catalysts were built via hydrothermal crystallization, and utilized for the hydrodeoxygenation of vanillin to produce 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol (MMP). The introduced Ga species were highly dispersed on series Ni/GaMFI catalysts, and framework Ga in Ni/GaMFI catalysts significantly improved the vanillin conversion and MMP selectivity by regulating the distribution of Ni nanoparticles and acid sites, which favored H2 activation and cleavage of CO bond. The high vanillin conversion (>99 %) and MMP selectivity (>99 %) were obtained on Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst under the experiment conditions (150 °C, 1.5 MPa H2 and 4 h), which was attributed to synergetic effect of open structural properties, dispersed Ni nanoparticles and suitable acidity. Finally, Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst demonstrated excellent activity stability during 5 recycles and universality for hydrodeoxygenation of various lignin derivatives. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hierarchical GaMFI zeolite Ni catalyst Hydrodeoxygenation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the excessive exploitation of non-renewable fossil fuels, the situation of converting lignin into high-value biofuels is very urgent [1,2]. However, lignin derivatives typically contain high oxygen content, which makes produced biofuels difficult to be used directly due to their low energy density, high viscosity, and unstable combustion [3]. The catalytic hydrodeoxygenation process can significantly reduce the oxygen content in lignin molecules, and has been regarded as one of the effective strategies to improve the quality of biofuels [4,5]. Vanillin, as a typical biomass derivative molecule, has been widely studied in the hydrodeoxygenation process [6,7]. In recent years, researchers have done plenty of work on the design of high-efficiency hydrodeoxygenation catalysts, including noble metal catalysts (Pt, Re and Au) and non-noble metal catalysts (Ni, Co and Cu) [8–10]. Noble metal catalysts have been reported the excellent activities in hydrodeoxygenation reactions due to their strong H2 activation ability [11]. However, compared to non-noble metal catalysts, the limitation of high-price hinders their industrial application. Up to now, researchers have invested generous efforts in the development of non-noble metal catalysts due to their economic affordability and high storage capacity [12,13]. Zhang et al. reported the flower-like biochar supported Cu catalysts with different pyrolysis temperature, and they found that Cu catalyst at 800 °C displayed a vanillin conversion of 99.7 % and MMP selectivity of 91.7 % at 170 oC, 2 h and 3 MPa H2 [14]. Gao et al. prepared Ni supported metal phosphate catalysts for vanillin hydrodeoxygenation, and a 97.25 % of vanillin conversion and 88.39 % of MMP selectivity were realized on Ni/ZrP catalyst under 220 °C, 0.5 MPa H2 and 30 min [15]. Numerous studies have revealed that non-noble metal catalysts could exhibit catalytic activity similar to noble metal catalysts under relatively harsh conditions. Therefore, designing non-noble metal catalysts with high-efficiency activity under mild conditions remains a major challenge. In the past few years, scientists have made many attempts to improve the catalytic performance of non-noble metal catalysts. Firstly, the preparation of bimetallic catalysts involves introducing a second metal species, such as NiMo, NiCo, and NiLa, etc. [16–18]. The results confirm that the bimetallic catalysts could significantly improve the activity and selectivity of hydrodeoxygenation reaction due to the formation of alloy sites, which could regulate the electronic structure and enhance acid sites of catalysts, thus facilitating the adsorption of reactant molecules and breakage of CO bonds [16]. Supports usually play a crucial role in catalyst preparation, since they can stabilize active metals to prevent sintering, and provide sufficient space for the reaction. Until now, various materials have been explored to prepare non-noble metal catalysts for hydrogenation reactions, including carbon materials, SiO2, CeO2 and zeolites [19–22]. Among them, zeolites have attracted special focus from researchers due to their excellent structural properties and high hydrothermal stability. However, the small pore size (< 2 nm) in zeolites limits their activity due to the difficulty of sufficient contact between macromolecule reactants and active sites. Therefore, some attempts have been made to improve the catalytic activities of zeolite catalysts by generating mesoporous channels [23,24]. Lee et al. studied the effect of NaOH treatment on Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst for vanillin hydrodeoxygenation [25]. The activity data indicated that the Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst treated with NaOH solution exhibited higher conversion and selectivity than untreated catalyst, which was ascribed to the NaOH treatment forming mesopores around Pd nanoparticles and adjusting the Brønsted acid sites of Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst. Etim et al. constructed the mesoporous NaY zeolite by the treatment of NH4HF2 solution, and found that treated Cu/NaY catalyst displayed the higher hydrogenation activity than untreated catalyst, which was closely related with the well-dispersed Cu nanoparticles in generating mesopores [26]. In recent years, researchers have found that introduced Ga species in zeolites have a significant impact on the catalytic activities of zeolite catalysts [27,28]. Bu et al. attempted to employ Ga-MFI zeolite as the support to develop Cu catalyst for propane dehydrogenation [29]. The activity data indicated that Cu/GaMFI catalyst exhibited high propane conversion (93.6 %) and aromatics selectivity (73 %), which was attributed to the appropriate acid strength brought by the doped Ga atoms in the framework, furthermore the introduced Cu species gave a suitable distribution of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. Verma et al. constructed bimetallic CuGa catalysts supported on nano-zeolite Y, and investigated different loading of Cu and Ga on hydrodeoxygenation reaction of various biomass molecules [30]. The results showed that 10Cu2Ga/nano-zeolite Y catalyst exhibited higher selectivity and conversion than other CuGa and monometallic catalysts, which was credited with the introduction of Ga species enhancing Lewis acidity, Cu dispersion and the generation of low coordinated Ga. Zhou et al. prepared the Ga modified mesoporous Y zeolite supported NiMo catalysts with different Ga/Al ratios for hydrogenation reaction of sulfur-containing compounds [31]. The highest catalytic performance was obtained on NiMo/MY-0.5Ga catalyst, resulting from doped Ga species providing the suitable acidic properties and appropriate distribution of NiMoS active phases. In summary, it has been confirmed that the doped Ga species not only significantly regulates the acidity of zeolite catalysts, but also promotes the distribution of active metals, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. Inspired by these studies, the hierarchical GaMFI zeolite anchored Ni catalysts were fabricated for vanillin hydrodeoxygenation to 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol (MMP). The series Ni/GaMFI catalysts were characterized with XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, NH3-TPD and TEM to investigate the effect of Ga species addition on structural properties, distribution of metallic Ni species and acidity in detail. 2 Experimental Synthesis of hierarchical GaMFI zeolite: The Ga modified MFI zeolite was synthesized using a modified hydrothermal method with TPAOH as the template [32]. Typically, TPAOH (8.12 g, 40 % solution) was added into the deionized water with vigorous stirring to form a clean solution; then TEOS (8.32 g) and different amounts of Ga(NO3)3 (0 g, 0.13 g, 0.25 g and 0.50 g) were mixed with the above clear solution and kept under stirring for another 4 h. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred to the autoclave and subjected to static heat treatment at 170 °C for 72 h. Afterwards, the white solid was acquired through centrifugation, dried at 100 °C for 12 h, and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h. The hierarchical GaMFI materials were prepared with the alkaline treatment process. The Ga modified MFI zeolites were mixed with 0.5 M NaOH solution under stirring at 60 °C for 3 h, and then quickly cooled to room temperature. After centrifugation, the hierarchical GaMFI zeolites were collected by drying overnight at 90 °C and calcining at 550 °C for 3 h, and denoted as xGaMFI, where x represented different Ga/Si molar ratios. Preparation of Ni/GaMFI catalysts: The Ni/GaMFI catalysts were prepared with the deposition-precipitation method. Firstly, 1.0 g of GaMFI materials and 0.57 g of Ni(NO3)2 were suspended in 50 ml of deionized water and kept at 60 °C with vigorous stirring. Then, Na2CO3 solution (0.5 M) was added to it until the pH reached 9–10. After stirring for 12 h at the same temperature to fully precipitate Ni species, the green solid was collected through centrifugation, drying overnight at 100 °C and calcining at 550 °C for 4 h, which was labelled as Ni/MFI, Ni/0.013GaMFI, Ni/0.025Ga/MFI, and Ni/0.05GaMFI, respectively. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 displays the wide-angle XRD characterization of series Ni/GaMFI catalysts, and it is notable from Fig. 1 that the Ni/GaMFI catalysts show the typical diffraction peaks attributing to MFI topological structure (PDF#79–0430) at 7–9° and 22–25° [33,34], illustrating the successful synthesis of MFI zeolite. The relative crystallinity (RC) of series Ni/GaMFI catalysts, calculated with the peak areas of different crystal planes by XRD characterization, was presented in Table S1. The RC values of various Ni/GaMFI catalysts decline slightly with the increase of Ga/Si molar ratios, indicating that the doped Ga species affect the ordered assembly of Si species to some extent. The peaks attributed to Ga2O3 species (PDF#20–0426) are not observed obviously on series Ni/GaMFI catalysts, confirming that introduced Ga species are highly dispersed over Ni/GaMFI catalysts [35,36]. Furthermore, the distribution of Ni species on Ni/GaMFI catalysts is presented in Fig. 1, and the diffraction peaks located at about 44.3° and 51.7° belong to metallic Ni species (PDF#87–0712) after hydrogen treatment [16,19], meanwhile the weak peak intensity of Ni/GaMFI catalysts proves that metallic Ni species are highly dispersed on the GaMFI zeolites. The morphologies of MFI and GaMFI zeolites are observed with SEM spectrum, and the images are presented in Fig. 2 . It is found from Fig. 2 that the MFI sample shows the relatively uniform particles with the size of 300–500 nm. Compared to this, the morphologies of 0.013GaMFI and 0.025GaMFI zeolites remain basically consistent; however, it is evident that the 0.05GaMFI zeolite is composed of smaller particles due to the excessive addition of Ga species. Fig. 3 displays the TEM images of Ni/MFI and Ni/0.025GaMFI catalysts, and the highly distributed Ni nanoparticles are clearly observed in Fig. 3(a) and (c), consistent with the XRD results (Fig. 1). From Fig. 3(b) and (d), the average size of Ni nanoparticles on Ni/0.025GaMFI catalysts decreases from 6.77 nm to 5.47 nm by contrast with Ni/MFI catalyst, confirming that Ga species addition promotes the distribution of metal nanoparticles. Furthermore, element mapping results in Fig. 3(f) illustrate that Ni and Ga elements are homogeneously dispersed on the Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst. Fig. 4 exhibits the N2 adsorption-desorption measurement of Ni/GaMFI catalysts, and it can be seen from Fig. 4(A) that Ni/GaMFI catalysts with alkaline treatment exhibit typical Type-Ⅳ isothermals within the relative pressure (P/P0 ) range of 0.45–0.90, confirming the existence of mesoporous channels [26,31]. The obvious isothermal with the P/P0 value of 0.90–1.00 on Ni/0.05GaMFI catalyst indicates the existence of intergranular pores [37,38]. The pore distribution of Ni/GaMFI catalysts is shown in Fig. 4(B). Except for Ni/0.05GaMFI catalyst, Ni/GaMFI catalysts possess the relatively concentrated pore distribution. Combining with Fig. 2 and 4(A), the wide pore distribution of Ni/0.05GaMFI catalyst might be caused by the excessive addition of Ga species leading to the distribution of smaller particles, thus forming the intergranular pores. Additionally, the detailed structural data of Ni/GaMFI catalysts is provided in Table S1. Compared to Ni/MFI catalyst, the specific surface area and volume of Ni/0.013GaMFI and Ni/0.025GaMFI catalysts have a slight downward trend, indicating that the introduced Ga species leads to the pore blockage of MFI zeolites to some extent. Obviously, series Ni/GaMFI catalysts display large pore volume (0.36∼0.42 cm3/g) and pore size (> 5.0 nm), which could favor sufficient contact between active sites and reactants, and promote the rapid diffusion of hydrodeoxygenation products in the channels. NH3-TPD analysis of Ni/GaMFI catalysts is presented in Fig. 5 . From Fig. 5, the signal located at 100–250 °C is assigned to the weak acid sites, while the signals at 250–500 °C and 500–750 °C are attributed to the moderate and strong acid sites [39,40]. It is notable from Fig. 5 and Table S3 that Ni/GaMFI catalysts show more acid sites than Ni/MFI catalyst, moreover the moderate and strong acid sites of Ni/GaMFI catalysts show an upward trend with the increase of Ga/Si molar ratios, proving that embedded Ga species could adjust the acidity of Ni/GaMFI catalysts. Series Ni/GaMFI catalysts are measured with XPS technique to analyze chemical valence of Ni, O, Ga and Si species. The XPS result of Ni 2p of Ni/GaMFI catalysts is presented in Fig. 6 (A), and the peaks observed at about 852.4 and 856.2 eV are attributed to Ni0 and Ni2+ species [16,18,19]. The “Satellite-state” peak found on 861.3 eV states that partial Ni species still exist in an oxidized state after hydrogen treatment [21,33]. It is noted that the intensity of “Satellite-state” peaks gradually weakens with the introduction of Ga species, illustrating that Ga species addition could enhance the reduction of Ni species. As shown in Table 1 , the proportion of Ni0 species on Ni/GaMFI catalysts changes with the order: Ni/0.025GaMFI (31.9 %) > Ni/0.05GaMFI (26.1 %) > Ni/0.013GaMFI (23.1 %) > Ni/MFI (16.7 %). Generally speaking, M0 (M=Cu, Co and Ni) is considered as the active site for hydrogen activation/dissociation and reactant adsorption in supported catalysts [41,42], thus the more Ni0 species could favor the hydrodeoxygenation of lignin derivatives. XPS analysis of O 1 s is supplied in Fig. 6(B), and the peaks corresponding to Si-O-Si and Si-O-Ga are observed at about 533.0 and 531.3 eV [43,44]. Notably, the peak intensity of Si-O-Ga gradually enhances with the addition of Ga species, supporting that more Ga species are embedded into structure of MFI materials. XPS result of Ga 2p over series Ni/GaMFI catalysts is displayed in Fig. 6(C), and the peaks found at about 20.6 and 18.7 eV are caused by Ga3+ and Ga0 species [45,46]. It is observed from Table 1 that Ga3+ is the main state of introduced Ga species on Ni/GaMFI catalysts. Meanwhile the binding energy of Ga 2p shifts towards lower energy with the increase of Ga species. Furthermore, the analysis of Si 2p on Ni/GaMFI catalysts is presented in Fig. 6(D). Compared to Ni/MFI catalyst, the binding energy of Ni/GaMFI catalysts displays a slight shift towards higher energy, indicating the presence of “electron-deficiency” state of Si species [47]. Considering the decrease in the binding energy of Ga species, an electron transfer might occur between Si and Ga species, thus forming the Si-O-Ga interaction to promote the reduction of Ni species on Ni/GaMFI catalysts. The performances of Ni/MFI and Ni/GaMFI catalysts are evaluated for vanillin (VAL) hydrodeoxygenation, and activity data are provided in Table 2 . It is noted that only vanillyl alcohol (HMP) and 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol (MMP) are found in the hydrodeoxygenation products. No hydrodeoxygenation products are detected without Ni catalyst addition. When Ni/MFI catalyst is employed for vanillin reaction, a nearly 87.2 % conversion of vanillin and 48.5 % selectivity of MMP is found, which might subject to its less acid sites and Ni0 species. As Ga species are introduced into Ni/MFI catalysts, the hydrodeoxygenation activities of Ni/GaMFI catalysts gradually enhance, and a > 99 % conversion of vanillin and 86.6 % selectivity of MMP are realized on Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst, which is superior to other Ni/GaMFI catalysts. Combining with characterization data, the excellent performance of Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst is credited with more Ni0 species for H2 activation, and its well acid capacity for the breakage of CO bond. It is also observed from Table S4 that Ni/GaMFI catalysts displays high vanillin conversion (>99 %) under the given reaction conditions, moreover the Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst presents >99 % MMP selectivity. Based on Table S5 and Figure S3, the Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst exhibits the highest turnover frequency (TOF) value of 10.09 h−1 and reaction rate constant (k) value of 0.0223 min−1, due to the synergistic effect of metallic Ni and acid sites. However, the selectivity of MMP on Ni/0.05GaMFI catalyst slightly decreases. Based on N2 adsorption-desorption and NH3-TPD analysis, the decrease of specific surface area and extensive strong acid sites on Ni/0.05GaMFI catalyst might limit hydroxylmethyl deprotonation ability. Considering the excellent activity of Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst, the influence of different reaction conditions on vanillin conversion and MMP selectivity has been investigated to reveal the hydrodeoxygenation process, and activity data are provided in Fig. 7 . From Fig. 7(a), the vanillin conversion remains almost unchanged within the range of 130–160 °C, but products distribution varies greatly at different reaction temperatures. It is found from Fig. 7(a) that only 65.8 % selectivity of MMP is observed when the reaction temperature is 130 °C. When temperature rises to 150 °C, a > 99 % selectivity of MMP appears on Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst, indicating that the high temperature is conductive to activating and breaking the CO bond. Nevertheless, with further increase of reaction temperature, selectivity of MMP remains almost consistent, and no other products are detected. Thus, 150 °C is regarded as the reaction temperature. Fig. 7(b) shows the activity result of different hydrogen pressures on Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst. By observing from Fig. 7(b), as hydrogen pressure increases from 0.5 MPa to 1.5 MPa, the selectivity of MMP enhances from about 53.5 % to >99 %. However, the selectivity of MMP remains almost consistent even with further increase of hydrogen pressure. Therefore, the optimal hydrogen pressure is regarded as 1.5 MPa on Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst. Fig. 7(c) displays the vanillin hydrodeoxygenation of different reaction times at 150 °C and 1.5 MPa on Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst. From Fig. 7(c), vanillin is almost completely converted with reaction time of 0.5 h Meanwhile HMP is the main component in the product, accounting for 75.1 %, and the content of MMP is very low, only about 24.9 %. With the extension of reaction time, vanillin conversion remains almost unchanged (>99 %); in contrast, the selectivity of HMP gradually decreases with increasing reaction time, while the selectivity of MMP gradually improves. When reaction lasts for 4 h, it is obvious that a high MMP selectivity (>99 %) is obtained. Afterwards, although the reaction time continues to extend, the selectivity of MMP remains largely unchanged. Hence, 4 h is considered as optimal reaction time on Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst. The recycling experiment of Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst is carried under the reaction conditions of 150 °C, 1.5 MPa and 2 h From Fig. 7(d), no significant decrease in vanillin conversion and MMP selectivity is observed during 5 cycles, confirming the strong stability of Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst. Additionally, the versatility of Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst is tested using various biomass-derived molecules, and activity results are presented in Table 3 . It is observed from Table 3 that the conversion of various reactant substrates is very high (>99 %) with excellent selectivity (>90 %) under the experiment conditions. However, the Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst shows the poor activity for 2-Bromobenzaldehyde, which might be ascribed to the existence of electron-withdrawing groups hindering the hydrodeoxygenation reaction. In general, these activity results of different lignin derivatives fully demonstrate the outstanding universality of Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst. A possible reaction network for vanillin hydrodeoxygenation is provided in Fig. 8 : H2 molecules undergo adsorption at Ni nanoparticle sites, activated and dissociated into active H species, then vanillin molecules adsorb on Ni nanoparticle sites and contact with surrounding active H species for rapid hydrogenation reaction to generate HMP. Subsequently, intermediate product HMP undergoes further hydrogenolysis reaction to crack CO bond and generate the target MMP. 4 Conclusion The hierarchical Ni/GaMFI catalysts with different Ga/Si molar ratios were built successfully, and applied for vanillin hydrodeoxygenation reaction. Combining with various characterizations, Ni/GaMFI catalysts could maintain high structural properties, supporting the decrease of diffusion resistance. Moreover, the introduction of Ga species not only increased the amount of acid sites, but also regulated the distribution of Ni species on Ni/GaMFI catalysts. The Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst displayed the high vanillin conversion (>99 %) and MMP selectivity (>99 %) due to its moderate acid properties and more Ni0 sites, meanwhile the outstanding stability and universality made it have a bright future in industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Fabricating highly active non-noble metal catalysts for hydrodeoxygenation of lignin derivatives is craving but still a challenge. Herein, hierarchical Ga-promoted Ni/MFI catalysts were built via hydrothermal crystallization, and utilized for the hydrodeoxygenation of vanillin to produce 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol (MMP). The introduced Ga species were highly dispersed on series Ni/GaMFI catalysts, and framework Ga in Ni/GaMFI catalysts significantly improved the vanillin conversion and MMP selectivity by regulating the distribution of Ni nanoparticles and acid sites, which favored H2 activation and cleavage of CO bond. The high vanillin conversion (>99 %) and MMP selectivity (>99 %) were obtained on Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst under the experiment conditions (150 °C, 1.5 MPa H2 and 4 h), which was attributed to synergetic effect of open structural properties, dispersed Ni nanoparticles and suitable acidity. Finally, Ni/0.025GaMFI catalyst demonstrated excellent activity stability during 5 recycles and universality for hydrodeoxygenation of various lignin derivatives.
